msDesc.head: Composite miscellany of literary, historical and devotional texts, mostly in Middle English

supportDesc.extent: ii (later paper) + 189 + i (later paper); one unfoliated later paper sheet inserted after fol. 1
supportDesc.collation: Medieval leaf signatures in the usual form in part II, showing that the quires were originally arranged as follows: fols. 77-89; fols. 52-76; fols. 141-158; fols. 159-177; fols. 31-51. All quires numbered 1-2, 6-16 in early modern ink, suggesting the loss of three quires between fols. 30 and 31 at a later stage. Parts II-III have an early common history, with part II seemingly supplemented by part III, and repairs made at the same time to part II (the replacement leaves fols. 52, 75-6 written by the same hand as fols. 125r-v, 128r-140r and replacement leaf fol. 159 apparently by the same hand as fols. 90r-124c, 126r-128r).

binding.p: 18th-century (?) red leather (probably goatskin) binding with gilt fillets around the edge of the covers; title on the spine 'Old English Poems'; fol. 1r, Bind this in vellum Turkey Leather.

history.provenance: 16th(?)-century title 'Lidgate', fol. 1r; occasional 16th/17th century annotations providing titles and authors, e.g fols. 52r, 91r; 17th- or 18th-century table of contents, front pastedown; fragment of an earlier label (?) pasted to fol. i recto, 90
Randal Drewe, late 16th or 17th century, effaced, fol. 1r; so read by Manly and Rickert.

William Howarde, late 16th or early 17th century, effaced, fol. 1r, but nevertheless identifiable (for example by comparison with British Library Arundel MS. 74 fol. 1r) as the ex libris of Lord William Howard (1563-1640)
M.S. Knox Ward Clarencieux (fol. 1r): Knox Ward, Clarenceux King of Arms 1726-41; his sale, 1749.
Richard Rawlinson, 1690–1755; his bookplate, upper pastedown.

recordHist.source: Description by Matthew Holford and Julia King, May 2022. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (W. D. Macray, Catalogi codicum manuscriptorum Bibliothecæ Bodleianæ...viri munificentissimi Ricardi Rawlinson, J.C.D., codicum...complectens, Quarto Catalogues V, 5 fascicles, 1862–1900). Decoration, localization and date follow Pächt and Alexander (1973). Quarto Catalogue, col. 28 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 29–30 Summary Catalogue, vol. 3, p. 206

ref.title: MLGB3: Medieval Libraries of Great Britain

listBibl.head: Select printed descriptions:
listBibl.bibl: S. Ogilvie-Thomson, The index of Middle English prose. Handlist XXIII, The Rawlinson Collection, Bodleian Library, Oxford (2017)
J. J. Griffiths, 'A Re-exanimation of Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Rawlinson C. 86', Archiv 219/134/2 (1983), 381-8
G. Guddat-Figge, Catalogue of Manuscripts containing Middle English Romances (1976), 288-292
Pächt and Alexander iii. 1027, pl. XCVII
J. M. Manly and E. Rickert, The Text of the Canterbury Tales (1940) I. 472-5

msItem.note: Miniature: see decoration. Fol. 1r blank except for later notes and names, see Provenance (above, for the whole volume).

msItem.title: The Northern Passion
msItem.incipit:
Off gostly Maters I wyll meve
To yow that are in cristis Beleve
msItem.explicit:
An C dayes also off Indulgens and pardon
And godde off hevyn is dere Benysvn
msItem.colophon:
Finitur iste liber
Sit scriptor liber.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit passio domini nostri Ihesu Christi composita a quodam sapientissimo in materna lingua videlicet anglicorum hominibus non intelligentibus scripturarum sensus
msItem.note: Ex libris of William Aylysburrey; see Provenance.

supportDesc.support: Mixed paper (folded in quarto) and parchment; the outer and central bifolia of each quire parchment. Watermark close to Briquet 2988 (used ?1417-1449).
supportDesc.collation: 1(22-2, 5 cancelled before fol. 5 and 20 cancelled before fol. 19, with no loss of text); 2(12-2 (?): 11 and 12 cancelled after fol. 30, no loss of text)

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., c. 36-38 lines; frame-ruled in crayon; ruled space c. 175–80 92

handDesc.handNote: One hand; predominantly secretary forms with occasional anglicana /a/ and /r/.

decoDesc.decoNote: Miniature (tinted and gilded drawing, possibly unfinished), fol. 1v: Crucifixion with Mary and John, Christ with a starburst on his chest, framed by a border with evangelist symbols at each corner.
Border of leaves and flowers in penwork with green and yellow wash (possibly unfinished), fol. 2r.
Seven-line decorated initial O, of reserved penwork on a ground of yellow wash with red highlighting, fol. 2r.
Two-line initials in red, with penwork in the ink of the text on fols. 2v-3r.
Elsewhere plain two-line initials in red.
First letter of each line touched in red; red rhyme-braces; decorative ascenders and descenders touched with red.

history.origin: 15th century, middle England, Norfolk (?) (LALME I.115 assigns language to Norfolk ('mixed, E Anglian and SE Midland English') noting that Bermondsey (see below) was a sister house of Thetford)
history.provenance: Bermondsey, Surrey, Cluniac priory and (from 1399) abbey of St Saviour (?): 'Iste liber constat Wyllelmus Aylysburrey monachus sancti Saluatoris de Bermudesay' (fol. 30v). (The original owner's name has been erased and W. A. etc. added.) (MLGB3: evidence from an inscription of ownership by an individual member of a religious house (which may not, however, be evidence for institutional ownership)). William Aylesbury likely identifiable as the monk of that name who occurs in 1519 (Griffiths, 383 n. 4).

msContents.textLang: Middle English with a little Latin

msItem.note: Originally blank (?); verses added by the main scribe (all printed Early English Meals and Manners, ed. F. J. Furnivall (1868), 219-220):

msItem.incipit: Utter thy langage wyth good a visement Reule the by Reason in thy termeӡ all
msItem.bibl: Seven lines; DIMEV 6137, this copy only

msItem.incipit: What man þu seruyst all wey him drede
msItem.bibl: Four lines; DIMEV 6242 (fully transcribed); identified at DIMEV 6137 as lines 64-7 of Peter Idley's Instructions.

msItem.incipit: Folus lade polys wisemen ete þe fysshe
msItem.bibl: Two lines; DIMEV 1333, this copy only, fully transcribed.

msItem.incipit: Who so in youthe no vertu vsith
Deame þe best in euery dowte
It is þe properte of A gentilman
Si vis dolere tua crimina dic miserere

msItem.author: Ranulf Higden
msItem.title: Polychronicon
msItem.note: (excerpts in anon. Middle English translation, not Trevisa's, IPMEP 605)
msItem.incipit: Josephus of Jewes þat nobyl was the first auctour of the booke of Policronica
msItem.explicit: accordyng to þe same. Explicit.
msItem.note: Followed by a historical note After þe begynnyng of the worlde in m. iiii. vi yere Brute landyd in Albian and Afore þe incarnac[i]on i m. ix. yere Gogmagog kyng of Albian gave many harde assautes to the Trogannis etc. (in full), then breaks off.

msItem.incipit: Adam had a sonne called seeth seeth had a sonne called enoch
msItem.explicit: but þis is not auctorysed kyng lanedin
msItem.note: A Biblical genealogy (IMEP XXIII.94 gives no other texts). Breaks off imperfect due to the loss of (at least) one leaf after fol. 50.

msItem.incipit: I sarvyd oure lady bothe nyghte and day
msItem.note: Diagrams of hands below, one tracing the leaf's watermark; names and pen-trials on fol. 51v, see Provenance.

msItem.title: The Tale of Jack and his Stepdame
msItem.incipit: God that died for us all
msItem.finalRubric: Here endyth þe tale of Jak and his stepdame
msItem.note: Fol. 52 is a supply leaf.

msItem.title: Verses, added by the main scribe

msItem.incipit: Who so in welth takyth non hede
Synge I wold but alas discedunt prospera grata
msItem.bibl: (DIMEV 4853, lines 1-4 only; possible cross-reference '123', '90' in the margin)

msItem.title: Who carps of birds of great gentries (Of hawks)
msItem.incipit: When men motyth of byrdys of gret gentres
msItem.explicit: And pulle of her bellys and let her flye to þe devell. Finis.

msItem.title: Veterinary recipe for a horse
msItem.rubric: A good medicine for þe paynes of a horsse
msItem.bibl: Given in full IMEP XXIII.94; added by the main scribe

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Dietary
msItem.incipit: Ffor health of body covere for colde þyn hede
msItem.explicit: To all indifferent þe rycheste dietarye. Finis.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Testament
msItem.incipit: Beholde man lyfte up þy eye and se
msItem.explicit: ffor þe I offerd my blode in sacrifice. Finis.

msItem.title: Appeal of Christ to Man
msItem.incipit: Late as I wente on myn pleyng
msItem.explicit: Quid vultra debui facere. Finis.

msItem.title: The Complaint of God
msItem.incipit: Thys is goddis avne compleynte
msItem.explicit: That euer we were to oure frende vnkynde. Finis.

msItem.title: A lament of the Virgin Mary ('Quia amore langueo')
msItem.incipit: In A tabernacle of A towre
msItem.explicit: To blysse Quia amore langueo. Finis.

msItem.title: ‘I wiyte my silf myn own woo’
msItem.incipit: In my youth full wylde I was
msItem.explicit: Or wite þy self þyn owne woo. Finis.

msItem.title: A lament of the Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit: In A chirche as I gan knele
msItem.explicit: for my sonne dyede my dere sonne dere. Finis.

msItem.title: A lament of the Virgin Mary ('Filius regis mortuus est')
msItem.incipit: As Ihesu rewlith myn reccheles mynde
msItem.explicit: That filius Regis mortuus est. Finis.
msItem.note: Fols. 75-6 apparently supply leaves.

msItem.author: John Lydgate (?)
msItem.title: On the Mutability of Man’s Nature due to the Seasons the Elements, the Complexions, and the Planets (Pageant of Knowledge)
msItem.incipit: The worlde so wyde þe ayre so remevabill
msItem.explicit: Towarde þat lyfe where Ioy is aye lastynge
msItem.note: The text extensively corrected.

msItem.title: Recipes (added, in the original hand) 'for the farcion', 'for the mygrym'.
msItem.note: Given in full IMEP XXIII.94.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Song of Vertu
msItem.incipit: As of hony men gadren swetnesse
msItem.explicit: With hym to dwell above þe sterrys clere

msItem.title: Recipes 'For the ache and yche', 'for the stone', 'for the hete in a mannys vysage', added by the main hand.
msItem.note: First and last given in full in IMEP XXIII.94

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Look in thy mirror
msItem.incipit: Towarde thende of frosty January
msItem.explicit: Loke wele your myrrours & deme none oþer wyght. Finis.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Verses against haste
msItem.incipit: All hast is odious wher as discrecion
msItem.explicit: Enbrace þat baner and do þer on a byde. Finis.

msItem.author: John Lydgate (?)
msItem.title: Stans Puer ad Mensam
msItem.rubric: Stands puer ad mensam made in Engles by þe monke of Bery called Lydgate
msItem.incipit: My dere chyld first þy selffe enable
msItem.explicit: Put all defavte vpon Iohn lydgate. Finis.

msItem.title: Recipes 'For the mygrym', 'For the paulsey', added in the main hand.
msItem.note: Given in full IMEP XXIII.94-5

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Horns Away
msItem.incipit: Of god and kynde procedeth all beavte
msItem.explicit: By exampill of her your hornes caste a waye. Finis.

msItem.author: John Gower (?)
msItem.title: Balade moral
msItem.incipit: Passe forthe þu pilgryme and brydell wele þi beste
msItem.explicit: Thow shalt haue hurt yf þu play with her longe
msItem.bibl: DIMEV 4346; here four stanzas only, probably imperfect due to the loss of a leaf.

msItem.note: For fols. 90-140 see below, part III.

msItem.author: John Lydgate (?)
msItem.title: That now is hay þat sumtyme was grasse
msItem.incipit: Ther is full lytel sicurnesse
msItem.explicit: Ther is no hey but all fressh grasse. Finis.
msItem.note: Lacking lines 54-117 as printed, due to the loss of a leaf after fol. 141.

msItem.incipit: Dum viuis et bene stas et sursum cornua gestas
msItem.explicit: Et caueas ne forte ruas cum stare puteris
msItem.note: Four lines; not in Walther.

msItem.title: The Treachery of Fortune
msItem.bibl: (DIMEV 4096, the only manuscript, possible a prologue to the following item)
msItem.incipit: O woeful worlde deceyvor of mankind
msItem.explicit: ffor fortune turneth sodenly. Finis.
msItem.note: Rubric in the original hand, but apparently a later addition.

msItem.author: Gilbert Banester
msItem.title: The Tale of Guiscardo and Ghismonda

msItem.incipit: Eche to othir þay suffir most payne
msItem.explicit: Whos corsis now lyeth in thayre chestis grauyd
msItem.note: Begins imperfect owing to the loss of two leaves before fol. 143.

msItem.title: Added recipe (main hand) 'For the ache in fete or arme of a man'.
msItem.note: Given in full IMEP XXIII.95

msItem.incipit: Whylome was þer an hygh & myghty prynce
msItem.explicit: Graunt þes lovers Ioy so endith my tale. Finis.

msItem.title: Added recipe (main hand) 'For the ache of the goute'.
msItem.note: Given in full IMEP XXIII.95

msItem.title: Love Poem
msItem.incipit: Myne hert is set vppon A lusty pynne
msItem.explicit: This ioy and I I trust shal neuer twyn
msItem.finalRubric: Finis quod Quene Elyzabeth ['quod ... Elyzabeth' a slightly later addition by the original scribe]

msItem.title: Computatio de feodis militum
msItem.note: Added (by the original scribe); on the number of counties, towns, parishes, knights' fees in England.

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Clerk’s Tale
msItem.incipit: There is ryght atte west syde of Italie
msItem.explicit: And euer to haue pacience in oure mynde
msItem.note: Lacking lines 83-211, 265-316, 367-417 due to the loss of two leaves after fol. 156, one leaf after fol. 157, and one leaf after fol. 158. Fol. 159 (lines 418-481) are a later (16th century) supply leaf; fol. 160r picks up at l. 485, so lines 482-4 are missing.
The quire is filled out by a number of shorter texts all in the original hand:

msItem.incipit: Clara dies Pauli bona tempora denotat anni
msItem.note: Verses on prognostication of the weather; four lines (Walter 2825).

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: Given in full IMEP XXIII.95

msItem.incipit: O tu fortuna cur non es omnibus una
msItem.note: Four lines (Walter 13013)

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: Given in full IMEP XXIII.95

msItem.title: On the death of Edward IV
msItem.incipit: Carmina qui letus cecini cano tristia mestus
msItem.explicit: Omnes Angligeni quia rex et tutor eorum
msItem.note: The only copy; not in Walther; pr. Anne F. Sutton and Livia Visser-Fuchs, 'Laments for the death of Edward IV: "It was a world to see him ride about"', The Ricardian 11, 145 (1999), 506-524 at 519-20.

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Prioress’s Prologue
msItem.incipit: O goode lorde thyn Name how mervelous
msItem.explicit: Tendyr myn songe þat I shall you saye

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Prioress’s Tale
msItem.incipit: Ther was in assye in the grete Cite
msItem.explicit: Evill shall þey haue þat evill deserue
msItem.note: Ends imperfect at line 632 due to the loss of a leaf after fol. 177.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Watermarks: (fol. 51, later supply leaf) glove with six-pointed star and three-part cuff (cf. fol. 159, but here on a chainline), (fol. 52, replacement leaf) glove with five-pointed star; (fols. 77-89) bull's head with six-pointed star, cf. Piccard IX.3-5 (c. 1460-75), (fols. 53-74, 141-158) bull's head with six-pointed star, eyes and nose, type Piccard IX.181-214 (c. 1448-80), (fols. 31-51, 160-177), hand with four-petalled flower, cf. Briquet 10708 (used 1478), a type not in Piccard; (fol. 159, replacement leaf), hand/glove with six-petalled flower and three-part cuff, type Piccard Online 155939-41 etc., used c. 1520.
supportDesc.collation: 3(22-1)('E', fols. 31-51: wants 21 after fol. 50, with loss of text, and fol. 51 is a later supply leaf), 4(24+1) ('b', fols. 52-76: fol. 76 added after 24; fols. 52 and 75-6 are later replacement leaves), 5(16-3) ('a', fols. 77-89: wants 1 before fol. 77, perhaps without loss of text, and 15-16 after fol. 89, probably with some loss of text) | 11(26-8) ('c', fols. 141-158, wants 1 before fol. 141 perhaps without loss of text, 3 before fol. 142 with loss of text, 5-6 before fol. 143 with loss of text, and 21-22 after fol. 156, 24 after fol. 157, 26 after fol. 158, all with loss of text), 12(22-3) ('d', fols. 159-177, wants 15-16 after fol. 172, no loss of text, and 22 after fol. 177, with loss of text; fol. 159 is a replacement supply leaf)

layoutDesc.layout: One column of usually 26-27 lines. No ruling; the paper has been folded to provide vertical guide-lines. Written space approximately 205–225 110

handDesc.handNote: Mostly one secretary hand; the supply leaves (fols. 52, 75, 76) in another later hand; supply leaf fol. 159 in another hand; both latter hands probably also found in part III.

decoDesc.decoNote: Added drawings of hands/gloves, fol. 51r-v (based on the watermark).

origin.origDate: 15th century, last third (at least in part after 1483), or early 16th century

history.provenance: Fol. 51v, 'Hamond Span', 'John Samson', possibly John Sampson (d. 1555) of London (Griffiths, 385).
Fol. 87v, 'Wylliam Warner the son of Thomas Warner', possibly William Warner (d. 1521) of London (Griffiths, 385).

msItem.note: Fol. 90r originally blank, for later pen-trials and additions see Provenance; fol. 90v blank.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Hors, Goose and Shepe
msItem.incipit: Contrauersies Plees and all discorde
msItem.explicit: That noman should haue of other disdeyn
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit a moralle tale of the horse the goose & the shepe

msItem.title: Piers of Fulham's Conceits in Love
msItem.incipit: A Man that loueth fisshyng & foulyng bothe
msItem.explicit: In oure tong Called Chilrage

msItem.title: Colyn Blowbols Testament
msItem.incipit: Whan that Bachus the myghti lorde
msItem.explicit: Lest thow be had in repreef and despite

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Legend of Good Women (Dido)
msItem.incipit: Glorie and honowre virgill mantuain
msItem.explicit: Rede ovide & In hym ye shall it fynde

msItem.title: Sir Landeval
msItem.incipit: Sothly by Arthurys day
msItem.explicit: Bryng vs to his blysse on high

msItem.title: The Wedding of Sir Gawain and Dame Ragnelle

rubric.add: The weddynge of sir gawen & dame Ragnell

msItem.incipit: Leythe and listenyth the lif of a lord riche
msItem.explicit: For paynes he hath strong
msItem.finalRubric: Here endyth the weddyng of syr gawen and dame Ragnell for helpyng of kyng Arthoure
msItem.note: Lacking about 70 lines (after l. 628 in Sir Gawain: Eleven Romances and Tales, ed. Thomas Hahn (1995)) due to the loss of a leaf before fol. 137.
A largely illegible note at the bottom of fol. 140r: see Griffiths 386 and Manly-Rickert I.474.
See Provenance.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Watermark: hand/glove with six-petalled flower/star and three-part cuff, between chainlines, type Piccard Online 155939-41 etc., used in the first half of the 16th century
supportDesc.collation: 6(8) (fols. 90-7), 7(10) (fols. 98-107), 8(16) (fols. 108-123), 9(14) (fols. 124-129, 129*-136), 10(6-1) (fols. 137-140, wanting 1 before fol. 137, with loss of text, and 6 after fol. 140, probably blank)

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., c. 28-34 lines; no ruling, paper folded to provide vertical guidelines; written space 220–235 135

handDesc.handNote: Apparently two scribes (A, fols. 90r-124v, 126r-128r6; B, fol. 125r-v, 128r7-140r); predominantly secretary forms.

decoDesc.decoNote: Plain initials with modest cadels, fol. 128v.

history.provenance: fol. 90r, various scribbles and pen-trials, and part of a release from 'John Hew' to 'Thomas John' of a property in Sussex; fol. 140v, note of items (including mazers, spoons) delivered 'to the good wiff Callwarly'; possibly (Griffiths, p. 386) the London goldsmith William Callawey and his wife Alice.

msItem.title: The Expedition of Henry V into France
msItem.incipit: God That all this world gane make
msItem.explicit: Blest be god yn trenyte
msItem.note: Rhyme-brackets to fol. 182v.
Fol. 186v blank except for pen-trials.

msItem.title: Verses on the kings of England
msItem.incipit: The myghte William Duke of Normandy
msItem.explicit: & is buried att Wyndesore
msItem.colophon:
Explicit per Johannem Reve free
Explicet per Johannem Reve
msItem.note: With genealogical roundels in the margins, outlined in red.

msItem.title: Note on the claim of Edward III to the throne of France
msItem.note: Fol. 189v blank except for pen-trials.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Watermarks, (fols. 178-80) hand/glove with six-petalled flower and unidentifiable device; (fols. 181, 185), hand/glove with five-petalled flower and unidentifiable device; (fol. 183), hand/glove with five-petalled flower and noose/flourish, somewhat resembling Piccard 17.5.1514 (Piccard Online 155779) (Windsor, 1522)

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., c. 36 lines; no ruling (paper folded for a vertical guide); written space c. 240 135

handDesc.handNote: Fols. 178r-184r: mostly anglicana, some secretary forms.

decoDesc.decoNote: 2-line plain red initial, fol. 178r; otherwise none.

origin.origDate: 15th century, late (after 1484) or 16th century, first half

revisionDesc.change: Description fully revised for publication on Digital Bodleian.
